addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord, the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

18 A
p
1593
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L. from
e Haghe.

page.lettertext:
fol.100r
May it please yo
r
good L. Having had some speeche
w
t
S
r
Francis Vere
, who hath signified unto me, what
hath passed at
e campe, in his dealing w
t
Count
Maurice
, I see no other hope of obtening
at demaunde
w
ch
he maketh for her
Ma
tie
then I have formerly de-
clared. For sith it was never but privatly re-
solved, and onely w
t
condition, If her Ma
tie
would
assist them, they will make no other answear but
privatly againe, and persist in
at condition, w
t
out
the whiche they have no meanes to compasse that ex-
ploit. The place to be assieged is so deere unto
the Enemie, as in every mans opinion he will straine
to relieve it, w
t
his uttermost power. And howe this
contrey will be able to maintene suche a siege, both
by land and by water, neither having a retraict,
nor force sufficient to attend
e Enemie, I knowe yo
r
L. doth consider. Were it so
at a newe Levie
of 2000 men would serve their turne, I should hope
by good inducements they might be wonne thereunto.
But they doe make their full account,
at with a
lesser armie, then ten or twelve thousand footemen
complete, and two or three thousand horsemen,
whereto I am assured they have not at this p
nt
,
above 6000 foote and 1500 horse, they must never
undertake it. It is not meete I should
presume, to move her Hig
es
to doe somwhat for
e
advancement of this action, because I knowe it is
considered, w
at
soever can be said, both for
e benefit of
her countrey, and for
e annoiance of
e Enemie. But
I am certainly persuaded, that if
e place be obtened
through her Hig
es
assistance,
e states may be drawen
to suche a reasonable treatie, as they will ether con-
descend to a present remboursment of all her charges,
fol.100v
upon
e taking of
e same, or deliver to her handes
e
possession of
e place. I knowe not whether her
Hig
es
be advertised thoroughly, of
e revenue
at is yelded
by
e villages and townes
at are of
at territorie. But
I have very good intelligence, and suche as I doe thinke
I may boldly write for certaine,
at heeretofore in time
of peace,
e contribution brought in to
e
Gouverno
r
of
that towne, hath amounted every moneth to ten thou-
sand poundes sterling: w
ch
summe at this present is
supposed to be greater: besides a further good it would
bring unto her Ma
tie
. That there should not in
Ostende
any garrison be needefull, but
e towne to be deman-
telled, or at lest so small a number, as seing it is
supposed
at 800 foote, and a 100 horse will suffice to
garde
e other, her Ma
ties
yerely charges would not growe
to be muche greater, then they are at this p
nt
.
Howsoever this attempt shall goe forward otherwise,
I doe thinke S
r
Francis Vere shall obtene an Englishe
Regiment, to be paied by this countrey, if her Hig
es
will permitte it: and I hope it will be moved in
the next assemblie of
e states, w
ch
may be perad-
venture about 15 daies hens. I will
not trouble yo
w
w
t
relating, w
at
we heare of their
proceedinges,
at are before
Gertrudenbergh,
for
at
S
r
Francis being there, can deliver it more directly.
But all occurrences agree,
at
e Enemie, er be long,
will come forward to their aide. Some thinke they
will endevo
r
, to divert us from
at enterprise, by plan-
ting a siege to some towne in this contrey: for whiche
the magistrates of
Breda,
Berghen up Zoome
Tertol,
steenberghen,
have written earnestly hither for war-
like provisions. S
r
Edward Norreis doth advertise
that by l
re
s intercepted, and prisoners lately taken,
fol.101r
he is perfitly informed,
at
e designe of
e Enemie
is all upon ostende: wherupon he doth require, to
be supplied of divers wantes. But for as muche as
those of
Zeland
doe signifie nothing of it, nor no
bruite is come of it from any other place, they make
light of it heere, assuring themselves,
at although
the Enemie should intend it, yet
e towne in all oc-
casions may be easely succoured. Howbeit to sa-
tisfie S
r
Edward Norreis, I have procured an order
for him, whereby he shall be furnished of all that
shall be needefull. This day we have
advertisment
at a pigeon of
e Enemie, w
ch
was
sent from
Boisleduke
to Gertrudenbergh, w
t
a l
re
of encouragem
t
, and w
t
promises of reliefe, was
taken by o
r
people. The letter was in cipher, but
presently deciphred, and an other letter written, w
t
the very same cipher, w
ch
was fastened to
e pigeon,
and sent into
e towne. The effect of it was, to
will them to signifie, by making of two fires at
a certaine houre in
e night, if they were in state
to holde out but 14 daies longer, before w
ch
time
they did not doubt, but to worke their deliverance.
But we knowe not yet heere, if
e fires were so
made at
e time assigned. Out of
Frise
we understand,
at
Co. William
and
e enemie,
mette bothe about a time, and at
e passage where
e Count did minde to erect his Fort: where bothe
their armies were ranged in order of battle, and so
continued together a good part of
e day. But
e
Enemie would doe nothing, having taken by pre-
vention
e narrowest part of
e passage, w
ch
was
fittest for a fort. Nevertheles
e Count doth
proceede in
e building of an other, in a place there
fol.101v
adjoining, by w
ch
he hopeth
at Groeninghen shall be
greatly distressed. Heere is
Coro-
nel Stuart
come lately out of
Scotland,
in message
from
e
Kinge:
of whose Instructions heereinclosed,
I have sent yo
w
a copie. It is interpreted heere,
at all
e other aricles, excepting
e last, as touching
his particular, and
at w
ch
is owing from
e states
unto him, are but maters of complement, and pur-
posely devised to grace his comming hither.
This
Councel of Estate
hath taken a resolu-
tion, to deprive
S
r
Thomas Morgan
of his gouvernm
t
in Berghen, upon divers pretenses. First for
at her
Ma
tie
had drawen her subjectes from thens, they
were sure
at her souldiers would not willingly
obey him. Secondly
at he had caried himself very
ill, in
e time of his gouvernm
t
, to
e prejudice of
e state. and thirdly they would no longer have
a gouverno
r
there, but as
ei doe in other places,
committe
e charge to
e Eldest Captaine: and ch
a
ge
as they see cause. I have opposed against them
as much as is possible, alleaging for
e Gouvernor,
that he is one of
e ancientest souldiers,
at hath ser-
ved this contrey,
at he was gone into his contrey,
w
t
their leave and good liking,
at their souldiers
have bin ruled very willingly by him,
at he never
yet refused, to come to answear any mater, wherew
t
they could charge him,
at to condemne him in his
absence, w
t
out
citing him first, it had no forme of any
equitie,
at it could not be but taken very ill by
her Ma
tie
and be offensive to all
at knewe it, w
t
other speeches to like purpose. What my pleading
will prevaile, I can not certainly say, because the
fol.102r
mater may happen to be resumed by them
But knowing, as I doe, their implacable humo
r
,
wheresoeover it takes a pitche, I am out of all hope
of their better proceeding. And besides I may con-
jecture by sundrie special tokens,
at Co. Maurice un-
derhande hath bin
e autor of this course, and doth
purpose, er be long, to place a favorit of his owne.
And so I take my humble leave. From
e Hage
18 A
p
1593.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
As I writte unto yo
r
L. in Fe
b
last, their designe
for this siege, hath bin imparted by
Mons
r
Buzenval
to
e
King,
who hath promised all
e aide
at he can
possibly spare, both of horsmen and footmen, and he
will joine w
t
their forces, at
e time of
e siege, if
any meanes shall be offered, to doe it c
o
veniently.
